page.title: Pacific Society for Reproductive Health Trust

revision.text:
{{orphan|date=April 2010}}
'''Pacific Society for Reproductive Health (PSRH) Trust''' has a membership of health professionals working in the many Island nations in the Pacific in the area of [[reproductive health]] and [[neonatology]]. Launched in 1995 in [[Port Vila]], [[Vanuatu]], the Society is registered as a Charitable Trust in New Zealand where the secretariat is housed in the Pacific Women's Health Research Unit at the University of Auckland.
The objectives of PSRH are to advocate for the improvement of maternal and child health across the Pacific by promoting and seeking educational opportunities for its members. More information can be obtained from the Secretariat at Middlemore Hospital, PB 93311, Auckland, New Zealand.
The PSRH and RANZOCG contributed in a major way to the report on "Making Maternal Health Matter"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fpi.org.nz/ParliamentaryGroup/NZPPDEvents.aspx|title=NZPPD Launches Report on Maternal Health in the Pacific|accessdate=13 March 2010}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/news/print.cfm?objectid=10598749|title=PNG asks for help over mothers' deaths |date=September 22, 2009|work=New Zealand Herald|accessdate=13 March 2010}}</ref>
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.psrh.org.nz/ Official site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pacific Society For Reproductive Health Trust}} [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in New Zealand]] [[Category:Women's health]] [[Category:Women in New Zealand]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} <!-- Not acted on so far for months, but a javascript pain so disabling them {{Expand French|Poly Implant Prothèse|date=January 2012}} {{Expand German|Poly Implant Prothèse|date=January 2012}}--> {{Infobox company | name = Poly Implant Prothèse | logo = [[File:PIP logo.svg]] | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = Liquidation in 2011 | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1991}} | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[La Seyne-sur-Mer]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Jean-Claude Mas (President) | industry = [[Prosthetics]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 120<ref name=rerg/> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Poly Implant Prothèse''' ('''PIP''') was a French company founded in 1991 that produced [[silicone gel]] [[breast implant]]s. The company was preemptively [[liquidation|liquidated]] in 2010 following the revelation that they had been illegally manufacturing and selling breast implants made from cheaper industrial-grade silicone since 2001 (instead of the mandated medical-grade silicone they had previously used). The hundreds of thousands of unapproved implants sold globally by PIP from 2001 to 2010 were found to have a 500% higher risk of [[Breast implant#Complications|rupturing or leaking]] than approved models, as well as being implicated in at several deaths due to systemic toxicity and several cases of induced [[breast cancer]]. The scandal, which produced fears of a massive health disaster, prompted a full recall of the company's implants by the French health ministry in 2010, by which time the company was already defunct.<ref name=stbr>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-breast-implants-idUSTRE7BM14420111224 |title=France, UK issue clashing advice on breast implants |author1=Love, B. |author2=Flynn, D. |work=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters |date=23 December 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Breast implants in hand 01.jpg|thumb|280px|Breast implant]] PIP was founded in 1991<ref name=stbr/> by the Frenchman<ref name=ia/> Jean-Claude Mas, born in 1939, a former [[butcher]] and later [[Pharmaceutical sales representative|medical sales representative]] for the [[Bristol-Myers Squibb|Bristol Myers]] company<ref name=tlback/> for 15 years.<ref name=gmmi/> Mas had previously teamed up with plastic surgeon Henri Arion, who had introduced breast implants to France in 1965.<ref name=tlback/> After Arion died in a plane crash, Mas went on alone and launched PIP in 1991.<ref>{{cite news |title=The terrifying story of how a former French butcher earned millions from selling faulty breast implants made from mattress filling |author=Steve Bird |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2080547/PIP-breast-implant-butcher-Jean-Claude-Mas-denies-manslaughter-charges.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=December 31, 2011 |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref>
==Scandal== Starting in 1991, the company produced approximately 2 million sets of silicone breast implants over a 20-year period. The implants were exported to Latin American countries such as [[Brazil]],<ref name=stbr/> [[Venezuela]]<ref name=nc/> and [[Argentina]], Western European markets including [[United Kingdom|Britain]] (25,000), [[Germany]], [[Spain]] and [[Italy]], as well as [[Australia]] (8900).<ref name=stbr/>
Following the FDA ruling in 2000 which banned silicone breast implants in the US market (leading to a slump in sales worldwide), Mas sought to "tighten PIP's belt" and recoup some of its lost [[market share]] by severely cutting costs. In particular, Mas was credited with the idea that by switching PIP's silicone from externally purchased medical-grade to in-house produced industrial-grade, huge savings (on the order of 90%) could be generated that would ensure profits remained high no matter the market. As one PIP engineer later noted, this decision involved a relatively small change in the formula for the silicone, enough so that only superficial differences in the end product were noted. However, none of the relevant regulations were followed for manufacturing medical implants, and no pre-launch tests were conducted.
== Timeline == 2000: Implant sales in [[United States|USA]] halted by an [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] launched moratorium on silicone implants.<ref name=uslaw/>
2001: PIP began to use unapproved in-house manufactured industrial-grade instead of [[Medical grade silicone|medical-grade]] [[silicone]] in the majority of its implants.<ref name=stbr/>
2003: the first signs of legal problems and financial losses can be traced by regulatory filings.<ref name=stbr/>
2009: Concerns surfaced in France first in 2009 when surgeons started reporting an abnormally high rupture rates. Which resulted in a flood of legal complaints and the company's bankruptcy.<ref name=stbr/>
2010: [[TÜV Rheinland]], headquartered in [[Germany]], gave a quality certificate to the production process used by the company until March 2010. However, this didn't apply to the type of silicone used. A former PIP worker and union chief, Eric Mariaccia said, "You had to have been a chemist to have noticed anything".<ref name=chiboss/> He also said that "The responsible ones aren't the workers but the heads of the company, notably the four who were linked to production and thus responsible for their quality".<ref name=chiboss/>
2010: In March 2010 PIP was placed into liquidation with losses of {{nowrap|9 million [[Euro|EUR]]}} after the French medical safety agency recalled its implants. In a subsequent inspection of the manufacturing site, the company was found to use unapproved industrial-grade, [[silicone]], with a cost of only 10% of an approved gel.<ref name=stbr/>
2011: On December 20 French officials say that an action plan is underway<ref name=gr/> following the death of a woman from [[Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma|ALCL]].<ref name=mhra-upd/> The French government recommended on December 23, 2011<ref name=rt/> that 30,000 women<ref name=stbr/> in France seek removal of breast implants made of a suspect silicone gel by the worldwide exporting PIP firm.<ref name=rt/>
== Issues == Medical problems arise when breast implants rupture and cause [[inflammation]] and [[irritation]]. Further, impure gel may also release toxic substances.<ref name=swbo/> Removing implants "carries risks in itself", says the French government.<ref name=stbr/> By the end of 2011, eight cases of [[Breast cancer|breast tumours]] had been uncovered in women after removing the implants, yet, while of concern,<ref name=swbo/> according to the French government, there is no evidence of any increased [[cancer]] risk.<ref name=stbr/>
The [[United Kingdom|UK]] medical watchdog, the [[Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency|Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Authority]] (MHRA), says France has reported rupture rates of around 5% for PIP implants, compared with 1% in the UK.<ref name=bbc-dd/> But a "leading cosmetic surgery firm" has privately warned ministers that the proportion of women at risk is as high as 8%.<ref name=in8/> Symptoms can include lumps around the implant or in the under-arm, inflammation in the breast tissue and a hardening of the breast.<ref name=in8>[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/exclusive-silicone-implant-risk-eight-times-greater-6283809.html independent.co.uk - Exclusive: Silicone implant risk 'eight times greater], 2012-01-01</ref> [[Patient UK]] says French regulatory authority has reported a rupture rate of up to 10%, with a gel leak in 11% of cases.<ref name=ptsc/>
Nigel Mercer of the [[British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons|British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons]] (BAAPS) says the French move was "certainly not unreasonable" but the British cosmetic surgeon Kevin Hancock said the divergent government responses would cause distress for British women. [[Plastic surgery|Plastic surgeon]] Hancock, of the [[Liverpool Women's Hospital]], says there were concerns in the profession over a high rupture rate and that "We are worried about the rupture risk because it is the rupture that brings the contents into direct contact with the body's tissues... We know that the contents were not what they were supposed to be. So in general we agree with the (French) decision to remove them".<ref name=stbr/>
Patients are used as "guinea pigs", said Nigel Mercer, a former president of the British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS), because medical implants lack the requirement of an independent [[clinical trial]].<ref name=bbc-al/>
The company sold a high-end product that used approved silicone for wealthier clients and which cost five times more than products with silicon gel manufactured in-house. Most PIP implants were manufactured with the in-house silicon. The lawyer, Haddad, representing the founder, said "There is a product made by PIP which did not formally receive the [regulators'] approval and in this regard there was a violation of regulations,". The company did not ask France's medical device safety regulators for approval of their in-house manufactured product, but expected it would have gotten approval if the company asked for it.<ref name=rerg/>
Cancer has been found in 20 women with the allegedly faulty PIP breast implants but French health authorities ([[Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé]] (AFSSAPS)) insisted there was still no proven link with the disease.<ref name=mx>[http://medicalxpress.com/news/2011-12-cancer-cases-french-women-pip.html medicalxpress.com - 20 cancer cases in French women with PIP implants: agency], 2011-12-30</ref>
AFSSAPS has as of 28 December,{{When|date=June 2012}} registered 15 cases of breast [[adenocarcinoma]], the most frequent form of breast cancer, one case of breast [[lymphoma]], two cases of other lymphoma, one case of [[lung cancer]] and one case of acute [[myelogenous leukemia]] in women with the implants.<ref name=mx/>
A French woman with a PIP breast implant where [[Capsular contracture|capsular]] [[Granulation tissue|scar tissue]] formed in the breast, which is a common occurrence with implants.<ref name=ptsc/> This tissue developed [[anaplastic large-cell lymphoma]] (ALCL), a rare form of cancer that affects the immune system cells.<ref name=mhra-upd/> The cancer caused death in this case and caused the French authorities to act.<ref name=mhra-upd/><!-- grammar check? -->
During the 672 registered preventive extractions, in 43 cases (6.4%) the implants had ruptured and in 14 cases (2.1%) they were "oozing", AFSSAPS said.<ref name=mx/>
The PIP implants have been resold as "Rofil M-implants".<ref name=tet/> British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS) believes many British women may have had the bad Rofil M-implants used when they bought cut-price breast enlargement surgery from clinics in [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Central Europe]].<ref name=tet/>
The PIP factory was shut down and their products banned after it was found they had used the chemicals Baysilone, Silopren and Rhodorsil in their implants.<ref name=tet/> These chemicals are normally used as [[List of gasoline additives|fuel additive]]s or in the manufacture of industrial [[Synthetic rubber|rubber]]<!--assumed synthetic, not natural--> tubing.<ref name=tet/>
In 1993, there was an availability crisis of silicone materials for use in medical long-term implant applications.<ref name=nush>[http://www.nusil.com/products/healthcare/index.aspx nusil.com - Healthcare products] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204224215/http://www.nusil.com/products/healthcare/index.aspx |date=4 February 2012 }}, 2012, read 2012-01-26</ref> In 1993, Mas ordered the staff to "hide the truth" and "We did it for 13 years without a problem".<ref name=gucont/> The PIP gel cost {{nowrap|5 [[Euro|EUR]]}} per litre while the authorized American gel Nusil cost {{nowrap|35 EUR}} per litre. The PIP implants were made with 75% non-authorised gel and 25% Nusil.<ref name=gucont/> "The material was better than that used to make the officially authorised gel," Mas said. "Usually, from 1997 onwards we hid the products used to make the PIP gel. I wasn't allowed to buy these products because they were not authorised. We organised everything to escape being monitored."<ref name=gucont/> Investigators interviewed Mas on 18 and 19 November 2010 after the French health authority [[Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé|AFSSAPS]] discovered the PIP breast implants did not conform to regulations. They passed the case to a judge who ordered a police inquiry for "aggravated deception".<ref name=gucont>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/06/french-breast-implant-firm-boss-unrepentant?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 guardian.co.uk - French breast implant firm boss unrepentant over unauthorised silicone], 2012-01-06</ref>
== Chest, testicle and buttock implants == The bad silicone has been used to make male [[chest]], [[testicle]]<ref name=tet/><ref name=ndt/><ref name=nzt/> and [[buttock]] implants as well.<ref name=nzt/> "Three people were specially trained to work with a machine that made silicon testicles'" said a former PIP worker.<ref name=nzt/><!--France's Le Parisien-->
Most of the male chest, buttock and testicle implants were exported to [[Latin America]].<ref name=nzt/>
== Impact per country ==
=== France === The French government recommended per December 23, 2011<ref name=rt/> that 30,000 women<ref name=stbr/> in France seek removal of breast implants made by PIP.<ref name=rt>REUTERS/Interpol/Handout</ref> For women that want to keep their implants, the state will pay for a six-month ultrasound scan.<ref name=bbc-dd/>
French public health care funds will be used to finance the recommended implant removals, at a cost estimated at {{nowrap|60 million [[Euro|EUR]]}}. New implants will be paid for in cases where they were used initially for medical reasons, others will need to finance a new implant by themselves. Associations representing women with PIP implants demand that public funds cover all cases. "This announcement is just a smokescreen and the victims of PIP are angry," said Alexandra Blachere, head of the association of PIP implant users in France.<ref name=stbr/>
A government [[Helpline|hotline]] has been set up by December 2011.<ref name=rerg/>
=== United Kingdom === In Britain, there are an estimated 30,000{{ndash}}40,000 affected women. The chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies said, "Women with PIP implants should not be unduly worried. We have no evidence of a link to cancer or an increased risk of rupture. If women are concerned they should speak to their surgeon". Removing the implant "carries risks in itself," she said.<ref name=stbr/>
Concerns were filed with the [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency|MHRA]] in 2009 when a lump was found during a [[Mammography|mammogram]] and [[Medical ultrasonography|ultrasound scan]] in a female patients breast but no action was taken by MHRA at the time.<ref name=bbc-al/>
Shadow Health Secretary [[Andy Burnham]] said private clinics in Britain that fitted PIP implants must be forced to pick up the cost of removing them.<ref name=tet/>
On 6 January 2012, [[National Health Service|NHS]] officials began to offer examinations and possible removal - in instances where a doctor ruled that necessary. They also called on private medical centers to offer the same deal to patients who had paid for private sector cosmetic surgery.<ref name=bhre>[http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2012/01/06/2338588/czech-republic-recommends-faulty.html bellinghamherald.com - Mixed advice in Europe over faulty breast implants], 2012-01-06</ref>
On 8 January 2012, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' reported that leading cosmetic surgeon [[Jan Stanek]] had conducted a study with colleague Mike Berry into PIP implants. Their report to the Journal of Plastic and Aesthetic Surgery revealed that, in an audit of 453 patients, between 16% and 34% of the PIP implants ruptured. This compared to a failure rate of less than 1% in other implants.<ref>Sarah-Kate Templeton, John Follain, 'Leak Rate Of Faulty Implants Is 1 in 3 In The UK' {{cite web |url=http://www.janstanek.com/file/comment_pdf_1326041882781050132.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524045639/http://www.janstanek.com/file/comment_pdf_1326041882781050132.pdf |archivedate=24 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}, The Sunday Times, 8 January 2012</ref>
=== Germany and Brazil === Germany's medical safety board and Brazil's health watchdog called for users of PIP implants to visit their doctor for checks.<ref name=stbr/>
On 6 January 2012 Germany's [[Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices]] recommended the removal of PIP breast implants as a precaution.<ref name=bhre/>
=== Netherlands === The bad breast implants were sold to about 1000 [[Dutch people|Dutch]] women under the name "M-implants" by the Dutch importer Rofil.<ref>{{cite news|title=Advocaat: artsen kozen voor die implantaten' (transl.: Lawyer: doctors opted for those implants|url= http://nos.nl/artikel/2047963-advocaat-artsen-kozen-voor-die-implantaten.html|publisher= [[NOS Nieuws]]|date= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Healthcare in the Netherlands|Dutch healthcare]] spokeswoman Diana Bouhys said, "We have advised them to consult their physician", but also declined to disclose the name of the company. PIP was the third largest maker of breast implants in the world.<ref name=gmmi>[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/242781/news/world/sub-standard-breast-implants-sold-to-dutch-firm-under-new-name gmanetwork.com - Sub-standard breast implants sold to Dutch firm under new name], 2011-12-27</ref>
=== Sweden === Approximately 5000 implants have already been sold, corresponding to an estimated 2500 Swedish women with the controversial implants. Nine clinics in Sweden has sold them says Gert Bruse of the [[Medical Products Agency (Sweden)|Swedish Medical Products Agency]] (Läkemedelsverket) told the [[Dagens Nyheter]] (DN) newspaper this week. The agency also recommends that the implants to be removed.
Sweden banned the company's implants in March 2010, along with many other European countries, when it was discovered that substandard silicone gel was causing unusually many implants to burst. "We've had cases where the implants have burst in Sweden, but it's fewer than in France in relation to how many women have these implants in both countries... Implants shouldn't burst and they shouldn't have an irritating effect that spreads throughout the body. What this company has done is criminal, simply put." said Bruse. PIP's implants have only been used in cosmetic breast augmentation surgery, not in reconstructive surgery.<ref name=swbo>[http://www.thelocal.se/38116/20111223/ thelocal.se - Swedish women warned over French fake boobs], 2011-12-23</ref>
=== Finland and Estonia === Patients from Finland often visit [[Tallinn]] to get cosmetic surgery. In October 2011 (two months before 22 December 2011), a Finnish woman in her 30s had received a different implant than what was agreed to in advance. An M-implant with the same type code as the implant from PIP was inserted instead of a promised [[Allergan]] implant. At least two Estonian clinics operating in Tallinn have offered M-implants as recently as December 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Finnish+woman+got+dangerous+breast+implant+in+Estonia/1135270081610|title=Finnish woman got dangerous breast implant in Estonia|date=2011-12-22|publisher=www.hs.fi}}</ref>
=== United States === Documents filed with the US government show that implants were sold until May 2000 through Heritage Worldwide, when the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] launched a moratorium on silicone implants. At the time, the US market accounted for 40% of Heritage Worldwide's revenues, or {{nowrap|3 million [[Euro|EUR]]}}, according to corporate documents filed in 2009 with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC). In 2007 significant losses started as both users and distributors filed complaints. Between 1996 and 2009, PIP was targeted by several dozen lawsuits in the United States, filed by users and business partners, claiming breach of contract or unmet payments. Starting in 2003, dozens of women began filing lawsuits mainly for product liability against PIP. However, as of 2009, no trial date had yet been set. Many of the lawsuits were later dismissed.<ref name=uslaw>[http://www.thelocal.fr/2128/20111227/ thelocal.fr - French breast implant maker faced US lawsuits], 2011-12-27</ref>
=== Italy === On 29 December Health Minister [[Renato Balduzzi]] said that hospitals and clinics are required to compile a list of women who has received breast implants from PIP. Even clinics that didn't use any PIP implants will be required to send a declaration stating that.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/Italy-orders-list-of-women-with-French-firms-implants jpost.com - Italy orders list of women with French firm's implants], 2011-12-29</ref>
=== Czech Republic === Czech Republic health ministry said about 2000 women with potentially faulty implants should have them removed.<ref name=bhre/>
=== Iceland === According to the Icelandic Directorate of Health, 440 women underwent breast surgery where PIP breast implants were used. The Ministry of Welfare have stated that health insured women will be offered counsel and ultrasound examination, free of charge. The Ministry of Welfare also stated that in the event that the implant is leaking, the government will pay a portion of the cost to have it removed.<ref name=gvre>[http://grapevine.is/Home/ReadArticle/Government-Will-Assist-With-Breast-Implant-Removal grapevine.is - Government Will Assist With Breast Implant Removal], 2012-01-10</ref>
=== Latin and South America === * Costa Rica - breast implants banned and taken off the market in March 2010<ref name=costric/> * Brazil - banned the breast implants on 30 December 2011, taken off the market in 2010<ref name=nc/> * Bolivia - implants replaced free of charge for some women on 29 December 2011<ref name=nc/> * Venezuela - promised to remove{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} them free of charge<ref name=nc/> * Ecuador - sales banned on 29 December 2011<ref name=nc/> * Argentina - ban<ref name=nc/> * Chile - ban<ref name=nc/> * Colombia - ban<ref name=nc/>
=== Iran === [[Ministry of Health and Medical Education (Iran)|Ministry of Health and Medical Education]] banned the breast implants and took them off the market in 2012. They advised women that used the products to consult with a doctor and if deemed a health threat, to have them removed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2012/01/120129_l21_cancer_pip_implantes.shtml|title=جمع آوری سیلیکون های غیراستاندارد پستان از بازار ایران|date= 2012-01-29}}</ref>
=== European Union === The adequacy of regulations on silicone-filled breast implants, investigation by the regulatory authorities and advice given to women implanted with PIP silicone pre-filled breast implants was criticized in December 2012 in a report examining information publicly available from the regulatory authorities.<ref name=qfi_pr25>{{cite web|title=Quality First International Limited Medical Devices Consultancy|url=http://www.qualityfirstint.com/info_center/pressreleases/pr25.htm|date=2013-01-07|accessdate=2013-01-17|publisher=qualityfirstint.com}}</ref>
== New company == A new firm has been registered under the name France Implant Technologie (FIT), with Mas' son Nicolas Lucciardi, 27, and daughter, Peggy Lucciardi, 24, at the address of their mother, Dominique Lucciardi, who was Mas' former civil partner.<ref name=nc/>
The local paper Nice-Matin obtained the business plan in which Mas is named as a "technical-commercial consultant" to the company and described as "a creative genius". Two former PIP managers were listed in senior positions in the company. With the objective to export implants to the "European, South American and Chinese markets". An investment of {{nowrap|2 million [[Euro|EUR]]}} was planned to put the former PIP plant back into operation, aiming to manufacture 400 implants a day with about 20 workers. However, Nicolas Lucciardi said that the project had collapsed due to media coverage of the scandal, adding, "That's obvious".<ref name=nc>[http://www.english.rfi.fr/americas/20111230-french-breast-implant-fraud-boss-tries-start-new-company rfi.fr - French breast implant fraud boss tries to start new company], 2011-12-30</ref>
== Legal process == The lawyer Yves Haddad is representing Mas.<ref name=stbr/> Legal complaints have been filed by 2500 women<ref name=nc/> in France and 250 women in Britain. Mas is wanted in <!--[[France]] and--> [[Costa Rica]] for "life and health" offenses, a warrant issued by [[Interpol]].<ref name=stbr/>
By February 2011, [[TÜV Rheinland]] sued PIP, claiming it had been "thoroughly and continuously misled" regarding the silicone used.<ref name=stbr/> Many [[Senior management|executive]]s are expected to face charges of [[aggravated fraud]] in an ongoing court case in France, expected to be scheduled for October 2012, which carries the possibility of [[prison]] terms of up to five years.<ref name=stbr/> The death of a cancer victim who had such implants may result in more serious charges of [[Manslaughter#Involuntary manslaughter|involuntary manslaughter]].<ref name=stbr/>
Frédéric Van Roekeghem, general director for La Caisse Nationale d'Assurance Maladie (French state social insurance agency, CNAM), will go to court regarding the complaints of bad implants. A criminal charge will be made within a few days he said to [[TF1]] on 25 December 2011. The decision has been made in consultation with minister of health, [[Xavier Bertrand]].<ref name=chiboss/>
Mas has recently undergone difficult surgery regarding a [[vascular]] problem that prevents him from walking said his lawyer Haddad.<ref name=gmmi/> Sources say a [[Marseille]]s court could soon announce fraud charges against four to six former PIP employees.<ref name=gmmi/>
A fraud case was filed against PIP on 30 December 2011 by France’s state-run health insurance fund (CNAM) officials in Marseille announced. Which is near the company’s laboratory at [[La Seyne-sur-Mer]].<ref name=nc/> On 26 January 2012<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> at just before 07:00<ref name=guarr/> the founder Mas was [[arrest]]ed in the home of a friend<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> in the [[Six-Fours-les-Plages|Six-Fours]] in [[Var (department)|the Var]]<ref name=guarr/> located in [[Southern France|South of France]] and taken into [[Police custody|custody]].<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> Investigators searched the house.<ref name=guarr/> A deputy chief executive was also arrested at his home.<ref name=guarr/>
Philippe Courtois, a lawyer represents 1300 women in France. Laurent Gaudon, represents four women and say a surgeon should inform about complications from both the surgery and devices used.<ref name=rerg/>
Nathalie Lozano, lawyer, represents more than 1400 women from Colombia, Argentina, United Kingdom and Venezuela. She claims TÜV Rheinland's gross negligence in the process of certifying the quality process.<ref name=impip_afectas>{{cite web|title=Afectadas por prótesis PIP | Lozano Blanco & Asociados|url=http://www.implantespip.com.co/|date=|accessdate=2013-02-06|publisher=implantespip.com.co}}</ref><!--Inserted by a user at ETB/Colombia on 2013-02-06 -->
On 17 April 2013, the trial of 5 executives in begun in [[Marseille]], France. Those charged are the company founder Mr Mas, who was booed in the court, his deputy Claude Couty, the quality director Hannelore Font, technical director Loic Gossart and products chief Thierry Brinon. They face up to five years in prison. The trial was expected to last until 17 May.<ref name="bbc_trialstart">{{cite web|title=BBC News - PIP implants scandal: Trial under way in Marseille|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22181137|date=|accessdate=2013-04-17|publisher=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
On 10 December 2013, Jean-Claude Mas was sent to prison for four years, and was fined 75,000 euros (£63,000) by a court in Marseille, France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Breast implants: PIP's Jean-Claude Mas gets jail sentence|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25315627|publisher=BBC News|date=10 December 2013|accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
== Aftermath == British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS) says that poor [[postmarketing surveillance]] is the root of the crisis, and proposes significantly more stringent monitoring of all medical devices including breast implants and all cosmetic injectables, via compulsory, regular reporting of adverse effects and [[mystery shopping]]. Professor Sir [[Bruce Keogh]], the [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] Medical Director, will look into whether the cosmetic surgery industry needs to be more effectively regulated.<ref name="bbc_lessons">{{cite web|title=BBC News - PIP breast implants: 'serious lessons must be learned'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-18057761|date=2012-05-14|accessdate=2013-04-17|publisher=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Health crisis]]
== References == <references> <ref name=ia>[http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/World/Story/STIStory_748452.html straitstimes.com - Interpol seeks arrest of breast implant company founder], 2011-12-24</ref> <ref name=tlback>[http://www.thelocal.fr/2143/20111229/ thelocal.fr - Breast implant tycoon hits back over scandal], 2011-12-29</ref> <ref name=chiboss>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-breast-implants-siliconetre7bn08i-20111224,0,1545242.story chicagotribune.com - French health minister wants implant boss found], 2010-10-14</ref> <ref name=gr>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/20/french-remove-breast-implants-silicone guardian.co.uk - French government 'to order women to remove defective breast implants'], 2011-12-20</ref> <ref name=mhra-upd>[http://www.mhra.gov.uk/NewsCentre/CON137888 mhra.gov.uk - Poly Implant Prosthese (PIP) breast implants update] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108094048/http://www.mhra.gov.uk/NewsCentre/CON137888 |date=8 January 2012 }}, 2011-12-23</ref> <ref name=bbc-dd>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16324216 bbc.co.uk - Breast implants: French boss sought 'for drunk driving'], 2011-12-24</ref> <ref name=ptsc>[http://news.patient.co.uk/newspaper.asp?ss=15&id=16658 patient.co.uk - 'Breast implants scrutinised after cancer death' - NHS Analysis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426090008/http://news.patient.co.uk/newspaper.asp?ss=15&id=16658 |date=26 April 2012 }}, 2011-12-21</ref> <ref name=bbc-al>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11739475 bbc.co.uk - Cosmetic surgeon concerned over 'guinea pig' patients], 2010-10-14</ref> <!-- 2012-01-06 testicle implants and chemicals --> <ref name=rerg>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/27/us-breast-implants-lawyer-idUSTRE7BQ0XN20111227 reuters.com - Regulators had not approved most PIP implants: lawyer], 2011-12-27</ref> <ref name=ndt>[http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/health/men-received-banned-silicone-chest-testicle-buttocks-implants-article-1.1001526 nydailynews.com - Men received banned silicone in chest, testicle implants, French PIP scandal grows], [[Daily News (New York)]] 2012-01-05</ref> <ref name=tet>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8993948/French-implant-company-used-same-silicone-in-male-chest-and-testicle-implants.html telegraph.co.uk - French implant company 'used same silicone in male chest and testicle implants'], 2012-01-05</ref>
<ref name=nzt>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/health/news/article.cfm?c_id=204&objectid=10777140 nzherald.co.nz - Testicle implants also contaminated - report], [[The New Zealand Herald]] 2012-01-06</ref><!--site photo?--> <!-- 2012-01-26 arrest --> <ref name=costric>[http://www.costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com/130-pip-implants-in-costa-rica-articles-la-nacion-and-ministerio-de-salud-archives.html costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com - PIP Implants in Costa Rica - La Nacion and Ministerio de Salud Costa Rica - extract of archives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530031900/http://www.costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com/130-pip-implants-in-costa-rica-articles-la-nacion-and-ministerio-de-salud-archives.html |date=30 May 2012 }}, 2012-01-26</ref><ref name=ibarr>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/287830/20120126/breast-implant-founder-french-police.htm ibtimes.co.uk - France: Faulty Breast Implant Firm PIP Founder Arrested], 2012-01-26</ref> <ref name=guarr>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/26/pip-implant-boss-arrested-france guardian.co.uk - PIP breast implant boss arrested in south of France], 2012-01-26</ref>
</references>
==External links== *[http://www.nhs.uk/news/2012/01January/Pages/government-review-advises-on-french-pip-breast-implants.aspx PIP breast implants – latest official news from the NHS] at the [[National Health Service]] website *[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Statistics/Performancedataandstatistics/PIPBreastImplants/index.htm PIP Breast Implants : Department of Health - Publications] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120618171416/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/watchdog/2012/04/pip_implants.html BBC - Watchdog: PIP breast implants] *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/14/breast-implant-scandal-private-sector guardian.co.uk - The breast implants scandal is bringing out the worst kinds of private sector attitudes], 2012-01-14
