GDP as a measure of wellbeing] (2012-12-22), Nicholas Oulton, ''[[Center for Economic and Policy Research]] (CEPR)'' * [http://www.voxeu.org/article/asking-people-which-aspects-wellbeing-matter-most Happiness and satisfaction are not everything: Toward wellbeing indices based on stated preference] (2015-01-02), Daniel J. Benjamin, Associate Professor of Economics, Cornell University; Samantha Cunningham, Project specialist, University of Southern California; Ori Heffetz, Associate Professor of Economics, Cornell University; Miles Kimball, Professor of Economics and Survey Research, University of Michigan; and Nichole Szembro, Assistant Professor of Economics, Trinity College.   ''[[Center for Economic and Policy Research]] (CEPR)'' * [http://www.voxeu.org/article/wellbeing-research-recessions-hurt-more-booms-help Busts hurt more than booms help: New lessons for growth policy from global wellbeing surveys] (2014-10-08), Jan-Emmanuel De Neve, Michael I. Norton, ''[[Center for Economic and Policy Research]] (CEPR)'' *[http://www.inner-light-in.com/2015/02/science-of-well-being-measurements-and-techniques/ Science of Wellbeing. Measurements and Techniques] Annie Wilson, 2014, Inner light publishers *[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/488724ec-9c9c-11e4-971b-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=uk#axzz3PIVV7arj Ditch the ‘wellness’ logs, charts, apps and get a life] (2015-01-18). "Most personal productivity measures are often a waste of time." ''[[The Financial Times]]'' * Ryff and Keyes 1995. page.title: World Health Imaging, Telemedicine, and Informatics Alliance

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = World Health Imaging, Telemedicine and Informatics Alliance | logo = Whialogo.JPG | logo_size = 200px | type = [[501(c)#501(c)(3)|501(c)(3)]] [[Non-profit Organization]] | founded_date = [[Chicago, IL]], US | location = [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]]
[[United States]] | founder = Mike Hoaglin, Dave Kelso, Matt Glucksberg, Michael Diamond | key_people = [[Newton N. Minow]], Chair of the Board
Michael W. Ferro, Jr., Vice Chair{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/board.html | title = Board of Directors}}
Ivy Walker, CEO
{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/personnel.html | title = Personnel}} | area_served = Worldwide | focus = [[Cost effective|Low-cost]] [[medical imaging]], [[X-ray]], [[Health information technology|Health Information technology]], [[sustainability]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = One digital image can save a life | homepage = [http://www.worldhealthimaging.org worldhealthimaging.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''World Health Imaging, Telemedicine and Informatics Alliance''' (WHITIA) is a non-profit [[global health]] technology and [[social venture]] established in 2006 by affiliates of [[Northwestern University]] near [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://magazine.mccormick.northwestern.edu/FA2007/Xray.html | title = McCormick students and faculty tackle health care challenge in the developing world | publisher= Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science, Northwestern University}}{{cite web | url=http://www.mccormick.northwestern.edu/news/articles/494 | title = World Health Imaging Alliance Partners For X-Rays in Developing World | publisher = McCormick School of Engineering | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} WHITIA cultivates high-level strategic relationships with [[non-governmental organizations]], [[medical imaging|imaging]] industry innovators and [[academic]] institutions in order to integrate and deliver meaningful, sustainable, [[diagnostic]] technology to underserved communities worldwide. WHITIA's vision is to facilitate the deployment of thousands of digital medical imaging systems worldwide, providing one billion people with access to diagnostic imaging.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/ |title=Welcome to WHITIA | Homepage |publisher=Worldhealthimaging.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-15}} WHITIA was formerly known as the World Health Imaging Alliance (WHIA) until it formally expanded its scope in June 2009. WHITIA's first formal public launch was in April 2009 at the [[HIMSS|Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS)]] Annual Conference & Exhibition in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. WHITIA announced strategic partners including [[SEDECAL]], [[Carestream Health]] and [[Merge Healthcare]], receiving extensive coverage in [[Health IT]] magazines and publications.{{cite news | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS111037+06-Apr-2009+BW20090406 | title = Not-for-Profit Has a Vision to Help a Billion People | publisher= Reuters | date=2009-04-06}}{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Merge-Healthcare-Commits-1-bw-14855801.html?x=1&.v=1 | title = World Health Imaging Alliance Poised to Bring Imaging Diagnostics and Data to the Developing World | publisher= Yahoo Finance}} At the 2009 Annual Conference of the Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine (SIIM) in [[Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]], WHITIA announced its partnership with [[Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine|SIIM]], which will allow both organizations to collaborate on specific initiatives.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090605005136/en | title = World Health Imaging Alliance (WHIA) Announces Support From The Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine (SIIM) | publisher= Business Wire}}{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.imagingeconomics.com/news/2009-06-17_01.asp | title = World Health Imaging Alliance poised to bring imaging diagnostics and data to the developing world | publisher= Imaging Economics}} WHITIA was recently ranked #15 of the top 25 most influential people, institutions, and organizations in the radiology industry.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | url = http://www.rt-image.com/25_Most_Influential_in_Radiology_Recognizing_the_movers_and_shakers_in_the_radio/content=9004J05E48B6A084409698724488B0441 | title = 25 Most Influential in Radiology | publisher= rt Image}} At the 2009 [[Radiological Society of North America|RSNA]] Annual Meeting, WHITIA launched, '''Remi-d''', a remote-operated screening X-ray system for use in the developing world. Its strengths in these areas stem from the higher burden of [[Human Immunodeficiency Virus]] (HIV) and [[Tuberculosis]] (TB) co-infection, high incidences of [[Coalworker's pneumoconiosis|Black Lung disease]], or outbreaks of other infectious [[respiratory diseases]]. The teleradiology and remote-controlled features of Remi-d allow resource-limited areas such as sub-Saharan Africa, South and Central America and Southeast Asia, where [[Radiologist]]s and [[Radiographer]]s are in short supply to have a functioning X-ray service.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-12-01 | url = http://www.news-medical.net/news/20091130/WHITIA-launches-digital-medical-X-ray-device-for-screening-infectious-diseases-in-developing-countries.aspx | title = WHITIA launches digital medical X-ray device for screening infectious diseases in developing countries | publisher= THE MEDICAL NEWS}} WHITIA currently has [[Pilot (experiment)|pilot]] [[System integration|integrated]] [[digital X-ray]] sites in [[South Africa]] and [[Guatemala]] at established [[clinics]] in need and is expanding to new qualified sites in [[partnership]] with [[NGOs]] such as [[Rotary International]] while cooperating with the [[local government|local]] and [[Central government|national governments]].{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.healthtechwire.com/The-Industry-s-News-unb.146+M5a262949a06.0.html | title = SIIM to Support World Health Imaging Alliance | publisher= HealthTech Wire}} == Guatemala clinics == The Guatemala pilot sites in urban [[Guatemala City]] and [[rural]] [[Río Hondo, Zacapa|Río Hondo]] provide essential healthcare technology to thousands of people in the communities served. They are designed to be models for the wider expansion of the WHITIA network throughout the clinics in need in urban and rural Guatemala. The system's specific design for Guatemala City is an integration of some of WHITIA's partners' strengths and generosity: * [[SEDECAL]] provides the X-ray generator and controls * [[Carestream Health]] donates the [[Photostimulated luminescence|computed radiography]] (CR) digital scanner and plates * [[Kane X-ray]] donates personnel to perform installation and set up of the CR and [[Picture archiving and communication system|PACS]] This project was largely funded by several US and Guatemalan [[Rotary International|Rotary clubs]] along with the key resource support of the Guatemalan municipal and national governments.{{cite web | accessdate = 2011-01-09 | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110104006502/en/WHITIA-Announces-Completion-Digital-X-ray-Pilot-Sites | title = WHITIA Announces the Completion of Digital X-ray Pilot Sites in Urban and Rural Guatemala | publisher= Business Wire}} == References == == External links == *[http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/ Official webpage] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sv0q0hD-flM Video interview with WHITIA staff and overview of mission. Shown at Rotary International Convention 2008] {{DEFAULTSORT:World Health Imaging, Telemedicine, And Informatics Alliance}} [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Illinois]] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:Health informatics and eHealth associations]]
